Rate my professor is so important these days. It'll save you so much time and money to avoid professors that are clearly phoning it in, or ones that only grade 4 exams and a final. There is no margin for error in those classes. If GPA wasnt so important I'd say take the difficult peofessors to learn more. At my school tho, a bad grade can ruin you forever because they don't allow replacement grades for transfer.

My strategy is is simple as doing as much practice problems as possible. For Physics, its pretty much calculations and some theory, so I do lots of practice problems, hard ones to extremely hard ones. Then for chemistry I review my notes and youtube to understand the theory behind the calculations and questions.

Rinse and repeat until test is done

MR. Organic Chemistry Tutor, when I took Engineering Physics I, II &III in the mid 1980's, I read each chapter three times, review lecture notes, write down all formulas on a 3 by 5 index cards and memorize them and finally I do all the problems at the end of each chapter. I took all my physics classes at the old Catonsville Community College in Catonsville, Maryland. All students, please choose your professor. The teacher makes a difference in the final grade. Another method for passing physics classes is to rewrite your notes at the end of each lecture. This will help you to remember all the important topics in physics.

Hey The Organic Chemistry Tutor,  I wanted to start off by saying your content is absolutely phenomenal! You have a way of natural talent for teaching and I commend you for that!  To answer some of your questions from the videos:  1. Some study techniques I find to be useful include study groups, asking teachers/professors/fellow classmates for assistance before tests and exams, summarizing chapters in your own words after review (if you can't, it may be a hint that you still have room to learn), and overall gaining a better intuition behind the material rather than memorizing formulas.   2. As a freshman in college, I made the mistake of not checking RateMyProfessors to select who I wanted as a Professor to teach the courses I was taking; luckily, I had 4 outstanding Professors that I wouldn't change for the world, even if I was given the opportunity! For this upcoming Spring Semester, I did, however, use the site this time to select Professors for the 5 courses I'm going to take. I've read some reviews on those who have great scorings and reviews on others with lower scorings and I found that it really is helpful to steer you away from teachers that will make learning difficult. I highly recommend taking his advice and using the site because it gives you insight on what the professor has to offer and how things roll in their classroom. For those who are curious, here's the link: https://www.ratemyprofessors.com/  Physics has always been a subject I've loved since I took it in High School and I can't wait to learn more about it through my years in College/University and eventually pursue that degree I've dreamt of for so long! Thanks for being an awesome and very helpful person OCT! Keep up the great work man!

Try putting yourself in exam similar situations. Such as, doing practice exams and setting your desk up in such a way, that there's no single distraction and only material laying there, that is needed for the exam. Getting familiar with such situations, will put you in an advantage during actual exams. That's at least how I was able to get rid of my exam anxiety, I would give it a shot
